reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency food assistance for vulnerable populations in Dana subdistrict.

description.narrative:
With the increasing rise of COVID-19 cases in northwest Syria as well as persistent violence and a weak economic system. Vulnerable people in Dana subdistrict face significant food challenges and the inability to access critical fresh food items. IDP, host community and returnee populations chronically lack the ability to access food, and COVID-19 items. Inflation has taken a serious toll on the prices of basic goods. IYD, therefore, proposes this response. This project will involve the provision of food assistance to 2,000 HHs
IYD, throughout this proposed project, is looking forward to meeting the food needs where many vulnerable families are either receiving inadequate food assistance or not receiving at all thus, IYD will implement the following activities: -Provide 1,000 HHs (2,250 males, 2,750 females, and 250 PWDs) living in Sarmada camps (Kamora Sarmada, Um Near, Bsakala, Salah Aldeen, and Dia'a 9 Kafroma ) with cash for food of $ 50 value on a monthly basis for 6 rounds to buy fresh food at the markets to prevent/reduce the risk of COVID-19 exposure. This activity will complement IYD’s ongoing project with WFP and will target the displaced people in Sarmada clusters who are not covered by WFP project. Building on IYD's current project with SCHF under number 15,000, this project will target the same locations and caseload to improve and sustain access to food for those most in need. In terms of market availability and accessibility, IYD has conducted a marketplace assessment to ensure that target populations are able to access the markets near them. Please see the attached marketplace assessments (vendors and buyers).
- Distribute 1,000 ready-to-eat food rations (out of the targeted camps mentioned above) to COVID patients, and people who have had contact with COVID patients and must apply home quarantine. Through this activity, IYD will secure sufficient food items and encourage people who may transmit the infection to apply home quarantine, and thereby, contributing to reduce the spread of COVID-19 in NWS.
Since the allocation paper encourages partners to prepare effective budgets, IYD decided to utilize its own resources to decrease the implementation cost, thus maximize the benefit earned per beneficiary.
